Actually, the brain does have it's own version of an advanced unilateral 
information compression system. If you think about it, simply put, it 
doesn't repeat certain things more than it has to after which point it 
relinks that notion back from every memory a party to it. That way you can 
reconnect a very large amounts of larger memory chains in a way that 
conserves space and overlaps over other chains. More over, our brains have 
developed an immense power of generalization (, which is actually a "power" 
saving feature, but I digress.)

comments.text:
The US went off the gold standard back in the 70's under the Nixon 
administration. Since then, all money derives its value from a central 
bank's regulation. As of right now, most of the world's money is based off 
reputation. When money is not based off a commodity(such as gold and 
silver), there is nothing to stop a central bank from printing and 
printing. In the case of the United States, the federal reserve, which is 
NOT a government agency, can print unlimited amounts of money without 
backing it up with anything physical. In the event that the US defaults on 
it's debt to the Chinese or any other lender, the dollar will ultimately 
collapse and could not be used as currency any longer. This is why you have 
people stocking up on gold and silver for a catastrophic collapse of the 
dollar. Realistically, it's inevitable that it will happen but the only 
question is when and how. The only thing preventing something like this 
from occurring is the reputation of the United States and it's military 
strength, as war will be the only way to stay relevant and powerful.

top_comment.text:
Actually, information is its own thing. It exists separately from mass and 
energy. And it exists independent of its medium. So like the story of Romeo 
and Juliet would exist regardless of what it was written on or in, like a 
paper book or in a computer. And since memories are information, they don't 
have weight.﻿
top_comment.author: J Frank

comments.text:
+SynchronizorVideos
There are a load of physicists who have worked all this stuff out already. 
You need matter and energy to have information.
comments.author: Speedyblupi

comments.text:
+J Frank Information doesn't have to be universally known to exist, but it 
does have to be known by someone, or, more broadly, recorded on something. 
 It can exist in different forms and in different mediums, but it does 
*require* that medium - whatever it is - in order to exist, and thus is 
fundamentally tied to that medium.  If that medium isn't matter or energy, 
what is it?
comments.author: SynchronizorVideos

comments.text:
+SynchronizorVideos Matter and energy are the things which transmit 
information. Just as paper and ink or a computer are the mediums for which 
a story might be told, understood, or shared; the story itself, or any 
other form of information, exists regardless of its own medium. Just 
because information is not known by us does not mean it does not exist. 
Claude Shannon laid out this theory in his 'Mathematical Theory of 
Communication,' which is the backbone of all discoveries of 
the Digital Age.
comments.author: J Frank

comments.text: +J Frank How can you have information without matter/energy?
comments.author: SynchronizorVideos

comments.text:
What does energy have to do with this? Information exists separately from 
matter or energy.
comments.author: J Frank

comments.text:
+J Frank
Looks like someone is forgetting E=MC^2
comments.author: Johnathan McNutt

comments.text:
+J Frank Information relies on matter to exist, and it is also constrained 
as such by physical laws.  For example, it is impossible to transmit 
information faster than the speed of light.  

Following your example, the information constituting Romeo & Juliet can be 
stored in different mediums or transmitted by different means, but no 
matter what, that information can only exist as arrangements of 
matter/energy, and can only be conveyed through physical interactions.  If 
all records (including memories) of Romeo & Juliet are erased or destroyed, 
the play will not live on in the aether or something, it will simply cease 
to exist.
comments.author: SynchronizorVideos

comments.text:
Information exists regardless of its medium. It might not be known, but 
it's still would exist. And yes the brain cells have mass, that is true. 
But the actual memories themselves do not. At least, that is my hypothesis. 
I very well could be wrong.
comments.author: J Frank

comments.text:
But information requires a medium for storage and transference, otherwise 
it can't exist.  Memories, for example, exist as arrangements of brain 
cells, which do have mass.
comments.author: SynchronizorVideos

captions.text:
Hey Vsauce I'm Jake and I have been playing
a lot of Grand Theft Auto 5 recently. Like,

a lot of GTA but we aren't here to talk about
my crippling addiction, we are here because

while playing I started thinking about how
heavy all the weapons I was carrying were,

so I found the closest real world counterparts
and with every weapon slot full, loaded with

ammo, you are carrying anywhere from 600 to
800 lbs. It would be like strapping a motorcycle
to your back.

According to the US Military, an infantry
soldier's fighting load should not exceed

48 pounds, or 33% their body weight. When
marching it should be around 72 pounds but

that has been known to go up close to 100.
In 1989, Doctor Joseph Knapik published a

study on loads carried by US military infantry
and interestingly points out that since the

Industrial Revolution, humans have grown an
estimated 10cm, and as we have gotten larger

in weight and height, the more we have been
given to carry.

Fictionally speaking however, GTA5 is but
a blip compared to what can be carried in

other games. In Minecraft, Steve can hold
a lot while still being able to run, jump

and climb. If we take the heaviest element
that exists both in the game and real life,

gold, fill all 36 inventory slots with 64
stacks of the stuff, it has been calculated

to weigh 44,467 metric tons...that Steve can
carry.

In the great video "The Biggest Organism on
Earth' Henry from Minute Earth points out

that the heaviest known organism is the Pando,
a clonal colony of over 47,000 Aspen trees

that are interconnected underground. It weighs
about 6,000 tonnes or 7.5 times less than
the gold Steve is cruising around with.

As of 2012 it was estimated that 174,000 tonnes
of gold have been mined, ever...in the entirety

of human history. So in Minecraft you can
carry 25% of all the Gold we have found so
far on Earth.

If you had that much gold in real life, it
would currently be equal to $1.88 trillion.

That could get you a trip to the moon and
back 2,506 times, over 2 trillion soft tacos

from Taco Bell, or you could reduce the US
National debt ... by 11%.

Obviously we can't carry that much gold or
that much of anything unassisted. So what

is the largest amount of weight a person has
carried? Patrik Baboumian, in September of

2013, took the world record for carrying 1,216lbs
for 10 meters. The most carried by any body.

The body. Every day we carry things with us
that aren't actually part of our body. Obviously

we have the clothes we are wearing, unless
you're not wearing clothes ... which is totally

fine ... but you are carrying inside you right
now about 4 pounds of bacteria.

In fact you and I have more bacterial cells
in our body than we do human ones. However

they are so small in size that they only make
up 1 to 3% of our body mass. Similarly, our

brains are 2% of our total weight but contain
massive amounts of information. Professor

of Psychology Paul Reber postulated that the
human brain has the memory capacity equal

to 2.5 petabytes, enough to hold 3 million
hours of TV. So then how much does a memory
weigh or an experience weigh?

Well no one has been able to measure the weight
of a memory in terms of mass yet but you can

measure its weight emotionally. Maybe saying
"I Love You" to someone and having it not

said back has more weight than that time you
got Bebop and Rocksteady action figures. We

have countless experiences and emotions stored
in our brains, and we personally assign an

importance to them, a weight. And maybe it
isn't the weight of the memory, but how we

carry it. Even though it can sometimes feels
like you are being crushed emotionally, that

you're stuck, that you can't move forward
- you still find a way to carry on. So next

time you think you've got heavy stuff on your
mind, think about poor ol' Steve and how he's

forced to carry as much as 25% of all the
gold ever mined on Earth ... and as always,
thanks for watching.
